question: How does quantum computing (QC) fit alongside classical computing?

answers.answer: QC can be better than classical computing for specific problems
QC can replace classical high-performance computing
QC can replace accelerators like GPU and FPGA
QC can efficiently process big volumes of data

question: What types of problems is quantum computing (QC) likely to be good at?

answers.answer: Efficiently simulate complex systems based on quantum mechanics
Improve accuracy/efficiency of optimisation and search problems
Optimise/accelerate certain parts of AI model training
Train AI models end-to-end
Render 3D models in complex simulations
Process data in real-time for high-throughput computing
Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum
Noisy Interim-Sized Quantum
Noisy Interim-Scale Quantum
Narrow Intermediate-Scale Quantum

question: Which of the following are limitations of NISQ systems for practical applications?

answers.answer: Noise & fidelity
Errors & decoherence
Storage space
Power consumption

question: What is decoherence in NISQ systems?

answers.answer: Uncontrolled change of quantum states causing information loss
Inability of quantum gates to communicate with each other
Inefficient connectivity between qubits in the NISQ system
Percentage of error-free operations in qubits

question: What type of skills are required for developing quantum computing applications?

answers.answer: Quantum information, algorithmics, programming & domain expertise
Quantum physics, mechanics & engineering
Algorithms & domain expertise
Data science, AI & programming

question: How is quantum computing currently being exploited?

answers.answer: Organisations that use classical computing are co-developing and/or investigating quantum computing
Quantum computing is useful only for scientists & researchers
Quantum computing is not yet useful to any organisation
Many sectors & organisations are developing operational/production applications

question: Which of the following are sister technologies of quantum computing?

answers.answer: Quantum cloning
Quantum simulation
Quantum communication
Quantum sensing/metrology
